docs.lead_paragraph: Dietary supplements now must carry more information on their labels, including complete lists of ingredients and levels of vitamins and minerals, according to regulations that went into effect last week. Jane Henney, the Food and Drug Administration Commissioner, said the action represented yet another step in the agency's continuing work to carry out the provisions of a new law regulating dietary supplements.
docs.abstract: FDA rules now require that dietary supplements carry more information on their labels, including complete lists of ingredients and levels of vitamins and minerals (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A large number of monkeys and lemurs in French zoos appear to be infected with the agent that causes ''mad cow disease,'' according to a provocative study published today in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. Although it is not the first time the disease has been found in monkeys and lemurs, the extent of the infection is surprising, researchers said. When 18 apparently healthy lemurs were killed and their tissues examined, every single animal was infected with what looked like mad cow disease. The finding is bad news for people living in Britain who fear that a human form of mad cow disease, called new variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, or C.J.D., may have similar underpinnings.

headline.main: 'Mad Cow Disease' Seen in French Zoos

docs.abstract: Large number of monkeys and lemurs in French zoos appear to be infected with agent that causes 'mad cow disease'; researchers' findings are published in Proceedings of National Academy of Sciences (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A gay New York pediatrician has enlisted 30 nursing mothers to supply breast milk for the baby he and his partner have adopted. The baby, now five months old, is thriving on the donated milk. In another part of town, a 19-year-old Bronx woman is being prosecuted for the death from starvation of the 7-week-old baby she had been faithfully nursing but inadequately nourishing.

headline.main: Breast Is Best for Babies, but Sometimes Mom Needs Help

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on advantages and disadvantages of breast-feeding of babies; says that as good as infant formulas now are, breast milk is still universally recognized as superior for first six months of life; offers guidelines on breast-feeding for new mothers, since nursing does not come naturally to either mothers or babies, who often need help in mastering this skill (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers have learned a great deal in recent years about female victims of sexual abuse and its often tragic consequences. But much less is known about men who are sexually abused. How often does it happen? And what are its effects? A British survey, the largest epidemiological study of nonconsensual sexual experiences in men to date, offers some preliminary answers. In the study, which appears in the current issue of The British Medical Journal, Prof. Michael King and his colleagues at the Royal Free and University College Medical School in London used computerized questionnaires to survey 2,474 male patients of 18 general practitioners in England.

headline.main: Sexual Abuse, When Men Are Victims

docs.abstract: British researchers find that 3 percent of men report having had nonconsensual sexual experiences after reaching age 16 and that 5 percent say they had been sexually abused as child; finds that when abuse occurred at age 16 and above, women are just as likely to be perpetrators as men (S)
docs.snippet: Researchers have learned a great deal in recent years about female victims of sexual abuse and its often tragic consequences. But much less is known about men who are sexually abused. How often does it happen? And what are its effects?    A British...

docs.lead_paragraph: Teen-agers fretting over how they look may not be just going through a phase. Some may be suffering from body dysmorphic disorder (B.D.D.), a severe preoccupation with an imagined or slight defect in appearance. This often secret and little recognized malady can lead sufferers to drop out of school, shun social contacts and even try suicide, say researchers at Brown University. B.D.D. is similar to anorexia nervosa except that sufferers worry about any aspect of their appearance, not just weight, explained Dr. Katharine A. Phillips, author of ''The Broken Mirror,'' a book on the disorder. ''They look O.K. but think they don't,'' she said. ''They worry they will be considered superficial or vain if they tell people about their concerns, but in reality they suffer incredibly.''

headline.main: A Devastating Disorder, Beyond a Phase

docs.abstract: Brown University researchers report on teen-agers who suffer from body dysmorphic disorder, severe preoccupation with an imagined or slight defect in appearance; this often secret and little recognized malady can lead sufferers to drop out of school, shun social contacts and even try suicide (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Back a thousand years ago, as a fearless beginner on the groomed, hard-packed slopes of the Northeast, I seemed to favor the point-the-skis-downhill-and-crash-at-the-bottom approach. A few years later, after a moderately undistinguished college-racing career, that basic style remained intact with a brief, and aborted, attempt at an entirely new discipline in the Austrian Alps: deep-powder skiing. That attempt ended with a crash at the top of the mountain, not the bottom, and two broken skis. Now, lured by the promise of warm spring sun, in high pure, untouched virgin snow, attracted as well by the idea of soaring with ease by helicopter up among the remote spires of the Canadian Rockies set in the greatest of imagined beauty, I ventured, several decades after that, to try again.

headline.main: Have Skis, Helicopter, Awe and Terror

docs.abstract: The Novice column on deep-powder skiing, in which skiiers are brought to top of mountain by helicopter, and ski down on top of soft, virgin, powder snow; drawings (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A popular technique to help infertile men become fathers, injecting individual sperm into individual eggs, alters the fertilization process, researchers have found. They said there was no evidence so far that the technique affected babies conceived with it but they said the finding raised troubling questions of what doctors should tell infertile couples. The technique, intercytoplasmic sperm injection, or ICSI (pronounced ICK-see), was developed about seven years ago and has been adopted by virtually every major infertility program. Tens of thousands of babies have been born through ICSI, which costs about at least $10,000 per pregnancy attempt.

headline.main: New Questions About Popular Fertilization Technique

docs.abstract: Researchers find that popular technique to help infertile men become fathers, injecting individual sperm into individual eggs, alters fertilization process; they say there is no evidence so far that technique affects babies conceived with it, but they say finding raises troubling questions of what doctors should tell infertile couples (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The early moments after patients are infected with the feared Ebola virus may be the most important to their survival, researchers report this week in the journal Nature Medicine. A French team working in Gabon in West Africa have taken and analyzed blood samples from 11 patients infected during outbreaks in Gabon and Congo. This sampling is in itself a feat because outbreaks have so far only taken place in very remote areas and because those who contract the disease die swiftly.

headline.main: Balanced Immune Response May Fight Ebola

docs.abstract: Response of immune system in early moments after patients are infected with Ebola virus may be the most critical for their survival; this is finding suggested by French team working in Gabon who took and analyzed blood samples from 11 patients infected during outbreaks in Gabon and Congo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The contraceptive sponge, once the most popular nonprescription birth-control device for women, could be available once more on drugstore shelves by fall. The Today Sponge, a convenient and well-liked contraceptive that was sold from 1983 until 1995, is scheduled to make a comeback through the efforts of a small pharmaceutical company that bought the rights to the product from the manufacturer that had ceased production of it.

headline.main: A Contraceptive Returns to the Market

docs.abstract: Contraceptive sponge, once the most popular nonprescription birth-control device for women, could be available once again by fall through efforts of Allendale Pharmaceuticals Inc, which has bought rights to product from Whitehall-Robins Healthcare; Whitehall-Robins ceased production of sponge in 1994, not because of health reasons, but because of manufacturing problems; photo of 'Seinfeld' character Elaine Benes, who hoarded sponges as supplies dwindled (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Jock Roy, 55, a businessman from Hanover, N.H., has suffered from peanut allergies ever since he bit into a peanut butter sandwich at a birthday party nearly 50 years ago. He described his reactions as beginning with a prickly sensation in the mouth and throat followed by a feeling of sickness and swelling of the throat and sinuses lasting up to four hours. Every year, about 100 people die from complications associated with allergic reactions to food, and peanuts and tree nuts are often the culprits. Now researchers at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine have taken the first small step toward preventing peanut allergy reactions in humans with an oral vaccination that seems to work on mice. Their findings appear in the current issue of the journal Nature Medicine.
docs.abstract: Researchers at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine take first small step toward preventing peanut allergy reaction in human with oral vaccination that seems to work on mice (S)
